subject: Re: [junit] Testing abstract classes
msgSnippet: ... If so, then why inherit? Inheritance is the way to reuse code that /does/ follow LSP, and the wrong way to reuse code that /doesn t/ follow LSP. ... Google
messageBody:
elmoseeriksen wrote:

> I read in the FAQ about testing abstract classes, but I do not
> understand the example given in the link the FAQ refers to.
> When I e.g. make the test class abstract, Eclipse gives the message
> "No JUnit tests found". Furthermore, my classes do not follow the
> Liskov Substitution Principle mentioned in the article.

If so, then why inherit? Inheritance is the way to reuse code that
/does/ follow LSP, and the wrong way to reuse code that /doesn't/ follow
LSP.

> If someone has a simple example of testing abstract classes with
> JUnit, or could explain it, I would really appreciate it.
> Or should an abstract class simply be tested through the classes that
> extends the abstract class?

Google site:c2.com abstract test case
